We provide new infrared photometric data for the giant low surface brightness galaxies (LSBGs) examined by van Dokkum et al. (2015).
We utilize these data to examine their stellar populations and dust content, and to assess whether they can be considered massive counterparts of local dwarf spheroidal galaxies.
The LSBGs have been detected in the J (1.25 µm), H (1.65 µm), Ks (2.17 µm), 3.6 µm, 4.5 µm, 5.8 µm, and 8.0 µm wavelengths using the Spitzer/IRAC and MIPS cameras on the Spitzer Space Telescope.

Our findings indicate that, with the exception of one galaxy, all others have an older population predominantly composed of red giants that are at least 1 billion years older than those typically observed in early-type galaxies.
Our analysis supports this observation, revealing that the majority of them exhibit minimal cold dust emission in comparison to other galaxy types.
These findings indicate that most of the LSBGs may be experiencing passive evolution, with little to no significant star formation activity over the past few billion years.
We provide updated observations of the molecular gas in the central region of the nearby galaxy NGC 891, acquired using the IRAM 30m telescope at 1mm and 3mm wavelengths.

The data indicate a widespread presence of dense molecular gas, with number density around \( n(H_2) \sim 10^4 \, \text{cm}^{-3} \) and a temperature of approximately \( T \sim 50 \, \text{K} \), linked to the optical disk of this edge-on spiral galaxy.

Our observations reveal two separate elements in the distribution of molecular gas. One component closely aligns with the dust lane observed in visible light images, while the other extends into the surrounding intergalactic medium.
This latter component has been identified by other researchers before; however, our higher resolution data enables us to distinguish it into individual clouds.
Through our observations, we identify several compact sources within the galactic plane that are probably young star-forming regions.
These findings indicate the possibility of a substantial reservoir of molecular material existing beyond the primary structure of galaxies like NGC 891.
We share the findings of our research regarding the potential existence and stability of terrestrial planets orbiting the star Gliese 581, situated approximately 20 light-years from Earth.
We conducted numerical simulations for various orbital configurations of three theoretical terrestrial planets, each with masses ranging from 1 to 10 times that of Earth (1-10 M⊕).
Our analysis indicates that all of these systems maintain dynamic stability over time scales exceeding 100 million years.
The largest planet possesses an eccentric orbit with an eccentricity of e = 0.2, and its periastron distance varies between 0.05 AU and 0.15 AU, depending on the initial conditions employed.
This planet can be classified as a hot Jupiter-like exoplanet due to its close orbit around its host star.
Nevertheless, we discover that there is another area where two or more terrestrial planets could coexist in a stable manner.
In this area, there may exist a super-Earth-type planet with a mass exceeding 5M⊕ but less than 8M⊕.

We investigate the enhancement of magnetic fields in supernova remnants (SNRs) caused by cosmic ray streaming instability, which arises from the anisotropic diffusion of energetic particles along the average magnetic field lines.
We demonstrate that this process could account for the magnetic field strengths observed in young supernova remnants and may provide insight into their origins.
The rate of instability growth is determined by the ratio of the gyrofrequency of relativistic protons to the frequency of the plasma waves they generate.
This ratio diminishes over time as the number density of accelerated particles increases in the region downstream of the shock front.
As a result, the instability stabilizes at a certain distance behind the shock front, where the magnetic energy density is similar to the kinetic energy density of the flow.
To estimate the saturation scale, we employ an analytical model recently introduced by Bell et al. (2013).
It enables us to determine the spectrum of amplified magnetic fluctuations generated by the instability caused by cosmic ray streaming.
We provide an analysis of the distribution of magnetic field geometries observed in stars along the upper main sequence (UMS).

We analyze data on the anticipated surface magnetic fields and rotation periods, along with stellar parameters obtained from spectroscopic observations, to assess the proportion of oblique rotators among UMS stars of varying masses and ages.
The outcomes were evaluated against predictions derived from dynamo models that take into account the influence of differential rotation.

Our analysis reveals that the proportion of stars with oblique rotation rises as the stellar mass decreases. Specifically, approximately 50% of F-type dwarfs exhibit this characteristic, compared to just 20% of G-type giants.
This trend can be clarified by the increasing complexity of the large-scale magnetic fields produced by dynamos located at the base of convective envelopes as stars evolve along the red giant branch.

We examine the fundamental characteristics of discrete choice models that incorporate social influence, where individuals make decisions based on their private information as well as the choices of those in their surrounding community.

We demonstrate that in the absence of correlation among individuals' private signals, any equilibrium must exhibit symmetry among individuals, meaning all equilibria are indistinguishable apart from the relabeling of individuals.
If there is a positive correlation among individuals' private signals, we demonstrate that asymmetric equilibria will always be present.
Finally, we present examples demonstrating that both types of equilibria can coexist in situations with intermediate levels of correlation.
These outcomes remain consistent whether or not the agents are aware of each other's payoffs.
Our analysis is fundamentally based on the latest developments in the theory of global games.
The core concept of our approach is to conceptualize an agent's decision-making challenge as a two-stage game involving uncertainty or "nature."
In the first stage, Nature selects a specific realization of the signal; in the second stage, her choice depends on the selected signal.

La gravité est une force fondamentale qui s'exerce sur tous les objets matériels, se manifestant par l'attraction entre eux.
La gravitation newtonienne ne peut seulement rendre compte du phénomène par lequel les corps tombent vers un point central au sein du système solaire.
Les théories relativistes d'Einstein ont permis de comprendre ce phénomène en introduisant le concept d'espace-temps courbe.
Cependant, il existe d'autres phénomènes physiques, comme l'effet Casimir et la pression de radiation électromagnétique, qui nécessitent l'ajout d'une nouvelle dimension à l'espace-temps.
Dans cette thèse, nous proposons d'intégrer une nouvelle dimension spatiale pour élargir la géométrie euclidienne classique.
Nous démontrons qu'il est possible d'interpréter la gravité comme une manifestation macroscopique d'un phénomène microscopique associé aux fluctuations quantiques de l'espace-temps.

Cette interprétation offre la possibilité de confirmer les prédictions théoriques de la physique contemporaine sur la dynamique des astres, tout en fournissant une explication logique à certains phénomènes physiques qui demeurent inexpliqués jusqu'à présent.

We introduce new characterizations for multivariable functions belonging to the Schur class, which consists of functions that are analytic in the open unit disk and adhere to specific growth conditions as they approach infinity.
We demonstrate the construction of these functions through an operator-theoretic method that utilizes the idea of a positive kernel.

The universe's first stars emerged from primordial gas clouds that collapsed under their own gravitational pull, forming dense cores that initiated nuclear fusion and transformed into scorching white dwarfs.

Cataclysmic Variables (CVs) are well-researched types of close binary star systems. They consist of a white dwarf that accumulates matter from a low-mass companion star via Roche lobe overflow.

Specifically, they provide valuable information about the formation processes of single and double degenerate white dwarfs, which are the predecessors of Type Ia supernovae.

We analyze the stability of planetary systems where protoplanetary embryos develop in an oligarchic regime, meaning they can gravitationally scatter and eject neighboring embryos but are unable to eject themselves.
We observe that this process results in the swift growth of the largest embryo until it attains its isolation mass, which is the minimum mass necessary for runaway accretion.
The system subsequently develops into either a single planet or two planets with similar masses, depending on the proximity of the initial conditions to instability.
This evolution differs significantly from the simultaneous growth of all bodies; specifically, we demonstrate that multiple stable outcomes can arise even when the initial conditions are the same.
Our findings indicate that the formation of terrestrial planets likely occurred in multiple stages, including an oligarchic phase, before arriving at their current state.
Furthermore, our research offers fresh perspectives on the formation of Mercury-like planets.
Protoplanetary embryos develop within the circumstellar disks surrounding young stars and interact gravitationally with one another as they grow.
These interactions result in orbital migration and dynamic instabilities, including collisions among adjacent embryos.
If these processes happen often enough, ultimately just one body will remain at the conclusion of the growth phase, resulting in a planetary system containing only a single planet.
Recent research indicates that numerous planetary systems host multiple planets, implying that some mechanism is in place to avert the total destruction of these systems.

In this study, we explore the potential for protoplanetary embryos to undergo a hierarchical evolutionary process. Initially, these embryos grow through gravitational scattering, and this is succeeded by runaway accretion once the largest embryo attains its isolation mass.
Through numerical simulations, we show that this scenario organically accounts for the existence of multi-planet systems and accurately reflects the characteristics of observed exoplanets.

We investigate thermal instability and fragmentation in a uniform, isothermal cloud surrounded by a hot plasma flow characterized by a constant velocity shear, utilizing two-dimensional hydrodynamic simulations.

The initial temperature difference between the cloud and its environment causes Rayleigh-Taylor instabilities to form at the cloud's boundary. These instabilities develop into mushroom-shaped structures that are also susceptible to Kelvin-Helmholtz instabilities.

Our analysis reveals that these two types of instabilities can result in the creation of filaments and clumps within the cloud, occurring over various timescales that are influenced by the intensity of the magnetic field.

Furthermore, we demonstrate that while heat conduction has minimal impact on the cloud's morphology, it plays a considerable role in shaping the cloud's internal structure by reducing density fluctuations.
In conclusion, we explore how our findings can help elucidate the phenomena observed in cometary globules and various dense molecular clouds.
Subject topics: Instability, Conductivity, Magnetic Fields, Clouds
We examine methods for encouraging cooperation among self-interested agents by incorporating a reward system into the spatial prisoners' dilemma (SPD).
In our model, every agent was positioned on a square lattice of size LxL, incorporating periodic boundary conditions.
At each time step, every agent engages solely with its four closest neighbors.

The payoff matrix for this game is defined by the relationships R > P > 0 > S < 0 < T. Our analysis shows that when T is set to 0.5R + 0.25P - 0.75S, cooperators can thrive even if they start with less than 25% of the total player population.
Additionally, we demonstrate that as the temptation to defect diminishes or the cost-to-benefit ratio rises, the proportion of cooperators tends to increase.
In conclusion, we show that the implementation of punishment not only preserves cooperative behavior but actually strengthens it.
Our findings indicate that the suggested reward mechanism could be beneficial for fostering cooperation in practical systems like biological communities and social networks.
Since the 1930s, the Russian school has been instrumental in the development of the concept of defects in crystals.
The core concept is that any crystal can be viewed as an elastic continuum, with certain local variations from its ideal structure referred to as defects.
In this study, we provide a concise overview of the historical development of defect theory in solids.
We also explore contemporary ideas regarding point-like defects (dislocations), line-like defects (disclinations), and continuous defects.
In conclusion, we provide illustrations of how these concepts have been utilized in various physical systems, including liquid crystals and magnetic materials.
Defects are significant in various fields of physics, including solid-state physics, condensed matter physics, and even biology.
They naturally emerge during phase transitions between organized states, such as those that happen at melting points or critical temperatures.
For instance, they can result in plastic deformations in metals or in materials that are glassy in nature.
On the other hand, defects play a crucial role in determining the macroscopic properties of solids, such as electrical conductivity and magnetization.

It has been demonstrated that for this system, there is a critical temperature, Tc, at which the entropy per spin decreases continuously to zero.

We introduce an algorithm designed to generate new solutions to the coupled Einstein-scalar field equations. This process begins with vacuum solutions, to which scalar fields are incorporated in a manner that ensures the resulting solution maintains minimal coupling.

This method can be employed to produce precise solutions that are either not explicitly known or are only given implicitly as functions of certain parameters, such as those obtained by solving algebraic equations.

We demonstrate our methodology through various examples, including Schwarzschild-de Sitter black holes, Reissner-Nordström-anti-de Sitter black holes, Kerr-Newman-AdS black holes, and charged dilatonic black holes.
Specifically, we demonstrate how to derive explicit formulas for the massless limit of these black hole solutions.
Our findings may also be relevant beyond the realm of gravity theory; for instance, in quantum mechanics, they could offer valuable insights into the nature of bound states.
Introduction: Exact solutions are crucial in theoretical physics because they enable us to evaluate different physical concepts by comparing them with specific predictions.
Nonetheless, locating precise solutions to physically intriguing problems frequently proves to be quite challenging.
For instance, over a century passed following the discovery of general relativity before the first precise solutions for black holes were identified [1-3].
Even now, numerous unanswered questions about black holes persist.
One reason that discovering exact solutions is particularly difficult is that most relevant theories do not provide straightforward analytic solutions.
Another challenge emerges when attempting to identify solutions for systems that involve multiple interacting components, such as black holes enveloped by matter or other fields.

In this context, one typically needs to numerically solve complex differential equations, which complicates the process of identifying all possible solutions, even when their existence is theoretically assured.

The situation becomes especially critical when attempting to analyze phenomena at strong coupling, as numerical methods lose their reliability due to significant corrections that stem from higher-order terms in perturbation theory.
We introduce the initial measurements of microlensing parallax obtained through infrared observations from the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE).
We utilize this data to determine the mass and distance of two lensing systems: OGLE-2011-BLG-0341L/MOA-2011-BLG-262S and MOA-2012-BLG-0171.
The former refers to an event where the source star approaches both lenses closely; our findings indicate that it has a total mass of 1.4 solar masses, located at a distance of 4 kpc.
The latter system is comprised of three components: the lens, its host star, and a distant companion, all of which are bound together by gravity.
This binary-lens event displays notable differences from typical single-lens behavior as a result of the influence of this third body.
By employing our novel measurement technique, we can calculate the mass ratio of the lens components and their apparent separation in the sky.
The aim was to assess the viability of Monoksa dorsiplana as an alternative biological control agent for managing Pseudopachymeria sp. (Bruchidae).
The parasitoids are collected in the laboratory and subsequently released onto P.sp.
Eggs were collected from females from various locations in Brazil, Argentina, and Paraguay.
Egg parasitism varied between 0.5% and 88%, depending on the location.
Under controlled conditions, the eggs that were parasitized hatched within a week.
Males appeared first, followed by the females.
Female longevity differed based on temperature, lasting between 11 to 21 days at 25 °C, 14 to 23 days at 20 °C, and 16 to 27 days at 15 °C.
Females laid eggs for as long as three weeks when provided with a honey solution.
This species is regarded as particularly favorable for mass production due to its substantial reproductive capacity and brief life cycle.
It can be effectively employed in integrated pest management strategies designed to minimize the harm caused by this insect pest.

We investigate the impact of AGN feedback on galaxy formation through hydrodynamical zoom-in cosmological simulations that employ various AGN feedback models, and we compare our findings to observational data.

Our fiducial model, which incorporates thermal energy injection into gas particles near black holes (BHs) alongside kinetic outflows resulting from BH winds, successfully replicates numerous observed characteristics of massive galaxies at z = 0. These include their stellar mass function, sizes, morphologies, star formation rates, metallicities, and cold gas fractions.

In this model, we observe that the majority of stars are formed within dark matter halos that have masses ranging from \(10^{11} \, M_{\odot}\) to \(5 \times 10^{12} \, M_{\odot}\), whereas halos with lower masses account for only approximately 10% of the total stellar formation.
Most of these low-mass halos contain dwarf galaxies or serve as satellite galaxies orbiting around more substantial central galaxies.
We report new spectroscopic observations of eight red giant stars located in the nearby dwarf spheroidal galaxy, Leo II, which is situated at a distance of 3 Mpc.
The data were collected using the Keck telescope and HIRES spectrograph across three nights in August 2005.
We measure heliocentric radial velocities between -150 and +50 km/sec.
These values align with earlier measurements conducted by other researchers employing various methods.
Based on the new data, we have concluded that there is no substantial rotation or streaming motion occurring within this system.
This finding aligns with theoretical predictions derived from N-body simulations, indicating that dark matter halos are likely to be nearly spherical structures.
Furthermore, our findings offer additional evidence arguing against the likelihood that Leo II harbors an intermediate mass black hole at its core.

Dwarf galaxies are intriguing cosmic structures that often harbor black holes and are surrounded by dark matter halos. The dynamics within these galaxies can be examined through rotation curves and stellar kinematics, which help us understand their gravitational influences. Additionally, many of these systems exhibit a degree of spherical symmetry, further facilitating our study of their characteristics and behavior.
We analyze higher-order angular correlations of galaxies by utilizing data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).
We utilize two-point correlation functions to assess the linear bias parameter, b1, for galaxies exhibiting varying luminosities and colors at redshifts ranging from z = 0.1 to 1.0.
The results were evaluated against predictions derived from perturbation theory, incorporating corrections up to the third order in the density field.
Furthermore, we investigate how the non-linear bias parameters b2 and b3 vary with redshift and color.
Our primary findings indicate that the measured values for b1 align closely with theoretical expectations, considering their uncertainties.

The second-order bias parameter b2 remains consistently close to zero for the majority of our sample, with the exception of faint blue galaxies at low redshifts, where it exhibits a positive value that rises as redshift decreases.
The third-order bias parameter b3 exhibits no considerable relationship with luminosity or color; however, its magnitude decreases significantly at higher redshifts.

We investigate the orbital evolution in the vicinity of galactic nuclei that harbor supermassive black holes (SMBHs) and demonstrate that the motion of these SMBHs can induce significant resonant interactions among stars. These interactions may explain certain observed phenomena, including nuclear star clusters and tidal disruption events.
We utilize N-body simulations to showcase how an eccentric supermassive black hole orbit contributes to the creation of several families of stable orbits in its vicinity.
The quantity of these families is determined by the mass ratio between the supermassive black hole (SMBH) and the bulge of its host galaxy.
For small mass ratios, we observe a single family of stable orbits. However, as this ratio increases by several orders of magnitude, new families of orbits begin to emerge.
These new families were distinguished by their significant eccentricities and inclinations in relation to the system's equatorial plane.
Furthermore, their periods differ significantly from those identified in earlier studies that assumed the SMBH followed circular orbits.
Lastly, we explore the potential observational signatures linked to each type of orbit.

The geometry and structure of halo nuclei are analyzed through their density distributions, derived from the solution of the Schrödinger equation using realistic nuclear potentials.
The findings indicate that the three-body force is crucial for the development of halo structures.
The density distribution of 11Li exhibits two peaks at greater distances, whereas both 6He and 8Be display a single peak each.
Furthermore, the density distribution of 12C is observed to have a tail that extends significantly beyond its core region.
These findings indicate that certain common characteristics are present among the four halo nuclei examined in this study.

We report findings on the cooling of metal and molecular gas in cosmological hydrodynamic simulations conducted with the Enzo code. Our focus is on the impact of various numerical methods for solving the energy equation, comparing smoothed particle hydrodynamics (SPH) to grid-based approaches, along with different physical models for star formation feedback.

Our analysis reveals that SPH codes generally overestimate the quantity of cold gas at high redshifts when compared to grid-based methods, a discrepancy attributed to the effects of artificial viscosity heating.
Feedback models that incorporate galactic winds can mitigate this effect by expelling low-entropy material from galaxies.
However, we also demonstrate that these wind models may result in an underestimation of the total mass fraction of cool gas if they excessively eliminate hot halo gas surrounding massive halos.

Our findings indicate that the latest galaxy formation models provide adequate estimates for the overall characteristics of the warm-hot intergalactic medium. However, they may still overlook crucial physical processes that influence the specific distribution of metals in individual galaxies.

In this study, we focus on decode-and-forward (DF) cooperation among nodes in wireless networks and introduce an optimal routing algorithm aimed at maximizing network throughput. This algorithm achieves this goal by jointly optimizing the routes from source to destination along with the paths taken by cooperative relays.
We frame the problem as a mixed integer linear programming (MILP) model, which is NP-hard because of its combinatorial characteristics.
To address this problem efficiently, we create two heuristic algorithms that operate with polynomial time complexity.
The first method employs a greedy strategy, continuously choosing the most optimal route for each pair of source-destination combinations until all flows have been successfully routed.
To enhance performance further, we have developed an additional algorithm that utilizes the simulated annealing technique.
Comprehensive simulation results indicate that our proposed algorithms demonstrate considerable enhancement compared to existing methods.
Keywords: Cooperative communication, Optimal routing, Simulated annealing, Greedy algorithm.

This paper presents an autonomous distributed admission control scheme designed to enhance both performance and fairness in wireless local area networks (WLANs).
The suggested scheme relies on the idea that each station tracks its own queue length information by utilizing the packet inter-arrival time at the physical layer.
Furthermore, it employs the count of active stations along with their transmission rates to decide if new connections can be accepted into the network.
Our simulation results demonstrate that our scheme outperforms existing approaches in terms of throughput while ensuring fair access for all competing stations.

We report spectropolarimetric observations conducted with the Solar Optical Telescope (SOT) aboard Hinode. Our findings indicate that the magnetic field strength derived from Stokes V profiles is consistently greater than the values obtained using the Zeeman splitting method for both the Ca II 8498 Å line and the Ca II 8542 Å line.
The disparity between these two methods grows larger as we move to smaller spatial scales.
Our findings indicate that, at smaller spatial scales, the magnetic fields are more oriented towards the solar surface than they are at larger scales.
These findings indicate the possibility of previously unidentified physical mechanisms influencing the creation of Stokes V profiles on small spatial scales.

We report on near-infrared (NIR) observations of the central region of the Carina Nebula, conducted using ISAAC at the VLT in Chile, and we compare our findings with earlier optical studies by Smith et al. (2000).
The NIR data uncover fresh insights into the structure of the nebular shell encircling the open cluster Trumpler 16.
We observe that the most luminous section of the shell is situated between two dark regions, likely resulting from dust extinction.
Through careful examination, we identified several small knots embedded within the shell.
These knots could be remnants of massive stars or protostars that originated during a prior phase of star formation activity in this area.
Ultimately, we discover several Herbig-Haro objects linked to the open clusters Trumpler 14 and 15.
Our findings indicate that star formation is still ongoing in the Carina Nebula.

We share the findings from our numerical simulations regarding planetary formation in debris disks that vary in mass, composition, and structure.
Our findings indicate that planets can form effectively, even when they are enveloped by substantial dusty disks that have up to ten times the mass of the minimum-mass solar nebula.
The disk structure is shown to have minimal influence on planet formation as long as there is sufficient surface density at greater distances to facilitate significant impacts.
Planets that develop in these types of disks are generally larger but less massive than those that form in typical protoplanetary disks.
This could clarify why certain extrasolar planets seem too small, while others appear excessively massive.
Our findings indicate that a significant number of terrestrial planets may exist around Sun-like stars, but they remain undetected due to their highly inclined or eccentric orbits.
Keywords: Formation of planets; Debris disks; Major collisions; Accretion of embryos.
We examine the susceptibility of interdependent networks to cascading failures, where nodes face random attacks and their neighboring nodes may also fail due to a loss of connectivity.
We demonstrate that dynamic effects heighten network vulnerability by accelerating the propagation of failures over time.
Specifically, our findings indicate that a rise in the number of attackers or a reduction in the recovery rate leads to a higher likelihood of global cascade failure.
Our findings indicate that it is essential to take into account both static and dynamic factors when examining the resilience of real-world systems to cascading failures.

We investigate the global polarization in the quark-gluon plasma (QGP) generated during non-central heavy-ion collisions by employing an effective chiral model that incorporates vector and axial-vector mesons, along with quarks and antiquarks.
Our analysis reveals that the overall polarization is predominantly influenced by the initial angular momentum of the colliding nuclei, which can be assessed using the Glauber model.
As the collision energy increases, the magnitude of global polarization decreases rapidly due to the growing number of particles participating in the reaction.
Our findings indicate that global polarization could reach approximately 10% at RHIC energies; however, this value is expected to decrease considerably at LHC energies.

Horizontal Gene Transfer (HGT) serves as a significant evolutionary mechanism that enhances genetic diversity and speeds up evolutionary processes. However, it can also have adverse consequences, including the disruption of co-adapted gene complexes and the introduction of harmful mutations into the genomes of recipient organisms.
In this study, we explore the impact of horizontal gene transfer (HGT) on the average fitness of unicellular organisms evolving in various environmental conditions by employing computational models.
Our findings indicate that horizontal gene transfer enhances the average fitness of cells in fluctuating environments characterized by high levels of stress.
Nevertheless, when fluctuations are minimal, HGT can reduce mean fitness by introducing detrimental mutations.
Ultimately, in stable environments free from external stresses, horizontal gene transfer (HGT) will have no impact on the average fitness.
Our findings indicate that horizontal gene transfer (HGT) likely played a crucial role in the early stages of life's evolution by enhancing its ability to adapt to shifting environments.
Horizontal Gene Transfer (HGT), which takes place among organisms with comparable DNA sequences, is recognized as one of the most essential evolutionary forces in contemporary biology [1].
It facilitates the swift acquisition of new genes, thereby enhancing genetic diversity within species.

We investigate the correlation function and entanglement entropy of one-dimensional quantum systems characterized by disordered interactions, with an emphasis on their scaling behavior over large distances and times.
We demonstrate that these quantities are interconnected through an exact formula that applies to both the ground state and thermal equilibrium states.
This relationship allows us to derive insights into the system's entanglement structure solely through measurements of correlations.
Specifically, we examine how this approach enables us to calculate the von Neumann entropy of the reduced density matrix for half of the chain, utilizing data gathered from numerical simulations.
I. INTRODUCTION
This work has two primary objectives.
Initially, we aim to share new findings regarding the connection between correlation functions and entanglement entropies in disordered quantum many-body systems.
Secondly, we aim to present a new method for calculating the entanglement properties of these systems that relies solely on measuring correlation functions.
We will delve deeper into this second aspect later on; for now, let's provide a brief overview of our main findings before we move on to the technical specifics.

We demonstrate that when an Iterated Function System (IFS) meets specific criteria, it can be represented as a unitary representation within its corresponding wavelet group.
This result is utilized to demonstrate that every self-similar fractal set with finite local complexity possesses a unique invariant measure, subject to scaling factors.
The proof is based on the idea that any fractal set can be approximated by a sequence of compact sets, each possessing boundaries with a Lebesgue measure of zero.
Specifically, we derive a novel characterization of self-affine carpets as fractals that meet this criterion.
In conclusion, we present examples that illustrate the application of our findings to several famous fractals, such as the Sierpinski gasket, Koch snowflake, von Koch curve, and Menger sponge.
The zeta function serves as a central focus in both number theory and algebraic geometry.
In this presentation, I will discuss how it can be utilized to investigate quantum field theories in curved spacetimes that possess non-trivial topological structures.

The fundamental concept is that we analyze the Feynman path integral across all fields in spacetime as an infinite-dimensional functional integration. This can be regularized by substituting the space of fields with a finite-dimensional vector space that has an appropriate norm.
This naturally introduces the idea of a "quantum torus," whose zeta function captures information regarding the spectrum of the associated quantum field theory (QFT).
Additionally, we will explore recent findings regarding the connection between the zeta functions of specific families of quantum tori and their corresponding modular forms.
Quantum Field Theory (QFT) has evolved into a robust approach for examining physical phenomena at their most basic level.
Nevertheless, numerous intriguing questions remain unresolved due to the challenges involved in conducting calculations that extend beyond perturbation theory.
One approach to overcoming these challenges is to draw on concepts from mathematics, specifically from number theory or algebraic geometry.
Specifically, we aim to utilize the "zeta-functions" associated with algebraic varieties to gain new perspectives on quantum field theories (QFTs).
These objects contain vital information about the fundamental physics, yet they are notoriously challenging to compute directly.
In my presentation, I will provide examples of successful explicit computations and demonstrate how these methods could advance our comprehension of quantum field theories (QFTs).

We investigate droplet excitations within a two-dimensional spin-glass model characterized by nearest-neighbor interactions and random ferromagnetic bonds. This system is recognized for possessing an infinite number of metastable states at zero temperature.

We demonstrate that this system exhibits two distinct types of droplets: the small droplets resemble those observed in previously studied models, while the larger droplets are defined by their fractal structure.
The latter category can be seen as an expansion of the droplet model that was previously suggested for three-dimensional Ising spin glasses.
Furthermore, we discover the existence of an additional category of excitations, referred to as "giant droplets," that are absent in any of these systems.
These large droplets account for the non-universal behavior seen in numerical observations close to the critical point.
In conclusion, we contend that our findings offer robust numerical evidence for the presence of a novel phase transition line separating the paramagnetic state from the spin-glass state.

Over the past 20 years, we have utilized archival data from the Very Large Array (VLA) to search for radio transients with flux densities between 0.1 and 1 mJy at frequencies between 4 and 8 GHz.
Our observations reveal that the majority of these sources originate from outside our galaxy; however, we also identify several Galactic objects, such as pulsars, supernova remnants, and flare stars.
Most of our sample consisted of previously uncatalogued sources, but we also identified numerous known variable sources, including blazars and gamma-ray burst afterglows.
Our findings underscore the effectiveness of integrating extensive archival VLA data into a unified dataset.
This research is funded by NSF grant AST-0907860.
In this letter, we provide an analysis of all archived Very Large Array (VLA) observations collected since 1990.
These data are gathered through a range of observing programs primarily focused on investigating distant galaxies or nearby star-forming regions.
Nonetheless, they hold important insights into the subtler transient events taking place within our Galaxy.

Through an analysis of over 10,000 hours of observation time spanning nearly 2,000 epochs, we have discovered thousands of new faint radio sources that appear just once or twice within the data sets of each epoch.

While many of these sources are extragalactic, we also observe a variety of Galactic objects, such as pulsar wind nebulae, supernova remnants, flare stars, and different types of active galactic nuclei.
Numerous recently identified sources were absent from current catalogs due to their low signal-to-noise ratio, which makes individual observations challenging.
By aggregating multiple epochs, we can enhance the sensitivity of our survey significantly, enabling us to detect even the faintest signals.
We investigate the impact of removing nodes in scale-free networks characterized by a power-law degree distribution P(k) ~ k^{-γ}, where γ falls within the range of 2 to 3.

Our observations indicate that when a single node is removed—either at random or based on its degree—the average path length increases logarithmically as we linearly increase the number of nodes removed.
The logarithmic increase can be understood by examining the impact that the removal of a node has on the shortest paths that pass through it.
The likelihood of an edge being part of such a path decreases exponentially as the distance from the removed node increases.
As a result, the majority of the edges impacted are those that were situated near the deleted node prior to its removal.
These short-range links create a small-world subnetwork surrounding each removed node.
Eliminating these local links results in longer distances within this subnetwork, while maintaining the overall global connectivity.
As a result, the cumulative impact of eliminating numerous nodes resembles the effect of introducing additional long-range connections into the system.

We provide an analysis of the spatial and velocity distributions of young stars (less than 10 million years old) located within 0.5 parsecs of Sgr A*, utilizing data from our spectroscopic survey conducted with Subaru/HDS.

Our analysis reveals that these stars are divided into two distinct groups along the line of sight: one group is situated approximately 0.1 parsecs to the west of Sgr A*, while the other is located around 0.3 parsecs to the east.
The first group has an average radial velocity of -200 km/sec, whereas the second group exhibits a velocity of +100 km/sec.

The findings indicate the presence of two separate groups of young stars surrounding Sgr A*: one linked to the clockwise disk-like structure observed in infrared images, and the other possibly connected to the counter-clockwise rotating ring-like feature recently identified by Genzel et al. (2003).
Additionally, we have discovered several new potential members of the clockwise disk population.
We provide millimeter (mm) and radio observations of four quasars with redshifts between 6 and 7, featuring the highest-redshift quasar identified to date.
Using the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA), we identify all sources in our sample that exhibit a high signal-to-noise ratio.

The spectral energy distributions that were observed align closely with models that incorporate both synchrotron radiation from relativistic jets and thermal dust emission produced by star formation activity.
Our findings indicate that these high-redshift quasars possess characteristics comparable to those observed in their lower-redshift counterparts.
These results indicate that massive black holes experience significant growth during this early period of cosmic history.

This study utilized data acquired from the ALMA program 2013.1.00010.S. Observations in the millimeter-wave and radio spectrum offer valuable insights into the physical processes taking place in distant galaxies.
Specifically, they can be utilized to investigate the growth history of supermassive black holes (SMBHs) that energize active galactic nuclei (AGNs).
In recent years, numerous candidates for supermassive black holes (SMBHs) have been identified at redshifts exceeding six, largely due to their prominent rest-frame ultraviolet (UV) continua [1].
Nonetheless, it is still uncertain how these objects develop over cosmological timescales, as there has been no direct detection of AGN signatures linked to them [2].

A highly promising approach for detecting AGN signatures is to observe the millimeter-wavelength continuum generated by hot electrons that are accelerated along magnetic field lines within relativistic jets [3], or through the free-free emission from the ionized gas surrounding the central engine [4].
Previous research has indicated that certain high-redshift quasars display strong mm-continuum fluxes [5, 6]; however, each study has only identified a single source [7, 8].
We present new observations in the millimeter and radio continuum of four quasars with redshifts ranging from 6 to 7, including the one with the highest redshift.
We provide an analysis of the distribution and characteristics of open clusters in the Galactic anticenter region, utilizing data from the Two Micron All Sky Survey (2MASS).
We have created a list of all open clusters that have angular diameters greater than 1 arcminute and are located within 8 kiloparsecs from the Sun.
The overall count is approximately 1,000.
This sample encompasses nearly all the well-known open clusters located in this region of the Galaxy.

By employing photometric distances obtained from fitting theoretical stellar evolutionary tracks to observed color-magnitude diagrams of each cluster, we create maps that illustrate their spatial distributions and luminosity functions.

Our findings indicate the presence of two separate populations of open clusters. The first population is situated at galactocentric radii ranging from 4 to 6 kpc and has ages younger than 3 billion years. The second population, on the other hand, is found at galactocentric radii exceeding 7 kpc, with ages older than 5 billion years.
We investigate the spread of information within networks characterized by multiple communities, each comprising its own distinct nodes and edges.
We present an epidemic model that reflects the impact of both global and local interactions among users across various communities.

The proposed model is founded on two main concepts: (1) we assume that certain influential individuals can disseminate information to their peers more rapidly than others; and (2) we permit cross-influences among adjacent communities through these influential figures.
Our primary objective is to comprehend how the architecture of the underlying network influences the spreading process.

**I. INTRODUCTORY REMARK**

In recent years, there has been a resurgence of interest in higher derivative theories of gravity, largely driven by their potential implications in quantum gravity phenomenology. Additionally, these theories offer intriguing alternatives to standard General Relativity (GR) within the framework of modified gravity scenarios.

Nonetheless, despite these endeavors, our comprehension of the physical implications of these theories is still lacking, primarily because of the technical challenges involved in analyzing their solutions.

A key challenge arises from the presence of derivatives of arbitrarily high order in the equations of motion derived from these actions, which renders them difficult or even impossible to solve analytically.
One approach to resolving this issue involves expanding the fields around a specific background solution and then truncating the resulting series after a finite number of terms.

Although this method provides valuable insights into the system's dynamics, it does not adequately account for significant aspects such as back-reaction effects between different modes of the same field or the interactions between various fields.

For instance, in inflationary cosmologies that utilize higher derivative gravity, the truncated perturbative expansions might fail to accurately reflect the observed levels of primordial non-Gaussianities.
A more structured approach to addressing these issues relies on covariant techniques that were originally developed in the context of General Relativity (GR).
These approaches enable us to clearly represent the equations of motion in a way that is explicitly gauge-invariant.

We showcase 8.4 GHz Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) images and light curves of the supernova remnant (SNR) linked to the Type IIb supernova SN2004et, which detonated in the nearby spiral galaxy NGC 6946 on September 24, 2004, UT1.
The radio emission is characterized by two prominent components that are approximately 0.5 arcseconds apart, consistently observed during all epochs from January 2005 to December 2007.
We observe that both components are expanding at speeds of approximately 5000 km/s, aligning with earlier estimates derived from single-dish observations.
Nevertheless, we observe notable proper motions of approximately 1000 km/s for each component during this timeframe.
These findings indicate that the Supernova Remnant (SNR) is approximately 3 years old, which corresponds to a distance of 4 megaparsecs to NGC 6946.
This measurement is considerably less than the distances previously estimated for this object using other techniques.
Our measurements offer new limitations for models of core-collapse supernovae.

Supernova remnants are the remnants of massive stars that have exploded at the end of their life cycle. These expansive clouds of gas and dust contain the elements produced during the star's lifetime and are crucial for the formation of new stars and planets. As they expand into space, these remnants contribute to the cosmic environment and enrich the interstellar medium with heavy elements.

We investigate the gravitational field produced by a massive scalar point source traveling along an equatorial circular geodesic around a Schwarzschild black hole. Our analysis is conducted through numerical evolution in two spatial dimensions (2+1) using the puncture method.
We observe that the perturbation is primarily influenced by a single mode that experiences exponential growth over time.
The growth rate aligns closely with the predictions derived from quasinormal modes for this system.
This finding indicates that the exponential growth could be linked to the instability of the scalar field in the vicinity of the horizon.

The Variable Star One-Shot project is an open-source software solution designed for analyzing astronomical data.
The project was created by researchers from the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA) in partnership with scientists from various institutions globally.

The aim of this project is to develop a comprehensive tool for analyzing various types of astronomical data sets, including photometric time series, spectroscopic observations, and images. One Shot Astro offers a variety of tools designed to swiftly and effectively analyze substantial volumes of astronomical data.

In addition to the main packages, the one-shot-astro repository offers numerous supplementary modules that enable users to conduct more specialized analyses. We offer fresh insights into the nuclear region of the nearby radio galaxy NGC 315, based on observations conducted with the Chandra X-ray Observatory (CXO) and the Very Large Array (VLA).

The CXO data indicate an unresolved point source located at the center of this elliptical galaxy, encircled by diffuse emission that extends approximately 1 arcminute (3 kpc). We interpret this diffuse emission as thermal gas heated by the central active galactic nucleus (AGN).
We observe two luminous knots within the broader emission, which are probably linked to shocks produced in the surrounding medium by the expanding radio jets.

By analyzing high-resolution VLA images captured concurrently with the CXO observation, we observe indications of a one-sided parsec-scale radio jet emanating from the nucleus at a position angle of PA = -45 degrees.
This jet has been observed on larger scales extending over several kiloparsecs.
Furthermore, there seems to be a fainter component of the radio jet situated to the southwest of the primary knot.

We introduce an enhanced semi-analytical method (SAM) that incorporates gravitational heating in dark matter halos along with gas cooling during galaxy formation. This approach is crucial for accurately replicating observed characteristics of galaxies, including luminosity functions across various redshifts.
We demonstrate that our SAM is capable of accurately explaining the evolution of the stellar mass function across cosmic time with appropriate parameters.

In conclusion, we explore potential enhancements to the model by incorporating additional physical processes such as supernova feedback and AGN activity.

We investigate the evaporation process of black holes (BHs) in an expanding universe through the application of the tunneling method and the WKB approximation.

Our analysis reveals that when the black hole (BH) masses are significantly larger than the critical mass \( M_c = 3 \times 10^8 M_{\odot} \), at which point the Hawking temperature is zero, the lifetime of the black hole decreases as its mass increases, following the relationship \( t \sim M^{-1/2} \).
For small black hole masses \( M < Mc^2 \), we demonstrate that the lifetime increases exponentially as \( M \) decreases.
The results are contrasted with those derived from quantum field theory in curved spacetime.
Our predictions align closely with these results when we consider the impact of back reaction caused by particle production during the evaporation process.

We investigate mesoscopic fluctuations in the supercurrents traversing two weakly coupled superconductors that exhibit varying transparencies and temperatures, employing the Usadel equations for quasiclassical Green's functions.

In conclusion, we explore the connection between our findings and the recent experiments conducted on diffusive SNS junctions.

We investigate the global structure and causal characteristics of (2 + 1)-dimensional Einstein spaces that have a nonnegative cosmological constant. These spaces are locally conformally flat but do not exhibit global conformality to Minkowski spacetime.
We demonstrate that these spaces can be categorized into three distinct types based on their overall structures, as outlined below:
Type I: The universal cover is homeomorphic to \( \mathbb{R} \times S^2 \).
Type II: The universal covering features an infinite number of ends.
Type III: Each universal covering is compact in nature.

Specifically, we demonstrate that any spacetime classified as Type I or II contains closed timelike curves if it features an incomplete null geodesic segment with endpoints that possess differing values of the affine parameter.

In our applications, we provide examples of comprehensive solutions for each category by explicitly constructing metrics on open subsets of the hyperbolic plane \( H^2 \), the complex projective line \( \mathbb{CP}^1 \), and the 3-sphere \( S^3 \).

**Introduction**  
In 2009, we announced the discovery of a new SW Sex type nova-like variable star, BH Lyn (Kato et al., 2009).
It exhibited a significant amplitude variation of approximately 3 magnitudes between its maximum and minimum brightness.

This object is categorized as a member of the SW Sex class due to its display of all the standard characteristics, including double-humped emission-line profiles, noticeable phase-dependent absorption lines, rapid flickering overlaying smooth sinusoidal variations, and prolonged deep eclipses that last for several hours.

Nonetheless, BH Lyn exhibits several distinguishing characteristics compared to other members of its class: it has a shorter orbital period (P orb = 0.084 d), a stronger magnetic field (B > 10 MG), and a higher mass transfer rate (Ṁ ~ 10−7 M⊙ yr−1).
These characteristics indicate that BH Lyn could be a potential progenitor of AM CVn systems.

We investigate the stability characteristics of circumnuclear disks (CNDs) located within elliptical galaxies, employing N-body simulations that incorporate dynamic dark matter halos and stellar components.
We observe that CNDs tend to remain stable against the formation of bars across a wide range of plausible disk parameters.

Nevertheless, we demonstrate that if the central black hole has sufficient mass to influence the gravitational potential at small radii, it can generate powerful bars or potentially obliterate the entire disk.
This finding indicates that a supermassive black hole could play a role in the formation of certain observed nuclear bars in nearby elliptical galaxies.

**Keywords:** Gravitational instability; Black holes; Bars; Nuclear activity; Galaxy evolution; Disk galaxies; Dark matter halos; Stellar dynamics; Cosmology  

**1 Introduction**  
Numerous researchers have drawn observational inferences regarding the presence of nuclear bars, utilizing photometric data (e.g., Laine et al. 2002; Erwin 2004).
Specifically, Erwin and Sparke (2003) discovered that approximately half of the early-type galaxies in their sample exhibit nuclear bars.
These findings indicate that nuclear bars are significant contributors to the evolution of galaxies.
For instance, they can supply fuel to active galactic nuclei by facilitating gas inflow into the core of the host galaxy (Shlosman et al. 1990).

Conversely, there are only a limited number of observational studies that directly identify nuclear bars using high-resolution imaging techniques like HST observations (Erwin 2004; Sheth et al. 2005). This scarcity is primarily due to the technical challenges involved in resolving highly compact structures located near the centers of distant galaxies.
Consequently, studying the theoretical aspects of the dynamic behavior of nuclear bars can enhance our understanding of their evolution over time.

2 Previous Research  
Several prior studies have examined the stability of nuclear bars in elliptical galaxies.

Athanassoula et al. (2005a) conducted numerical experiments in which they incorporated a rigidly rotating spherical component, symbolizing a bulge, into a model that included a live halo and a rigidly rotating disk.
They demonstrated that the system becomes unstable when the mass ratio of the bulge to the disk surpasses a critical threshold.

We positing that if a task does not finish processing by its deadline, all subsequent tasks associated with that job will be considered lost.

We analyze the distribution of magnetic flux in coronal holes (CHs) in comparison to quiet regions, utilizing vector magnetograms obtained from Hinode/SOT/SP.
Our observations indicate that coronal holes (CHs) exhibit a greater number of open field lines compared to quiet regions; however, they also encompass numerous closed loops.
At all altitudes above the photosphere, the total unsigned magnetic flux density is greater in active regions compared to quiet areas.

Alongside the variation in the amount of magnetic flux, we observed differences in the spatial distributions; specifically, the magnetic flux density diminishes more rapidly with height in coronal holes than in quiet regions.
This finding indicates that there could be variations in the physical processes taking place in these two different solar regions.

The solar corona consists of various features such as vector magnetograms, open field lines, closed loops, coronal holes, and quiet regions. Each of these elements plays a crucial role in understanding the complex structure and dynamics of the corona surrounding the Sun.

The measurement calculus is an advancement of the conventional quantum mechanics framework that facilitates measurements on composite systems. It has been utilized in several recent studies, including this thesis.

The core concept of measurement calculus is to treat each possible outcome of a measurement process as distinct states of the system being examined, rather than focusing on a single outcome, as was done by von Neumann.
This method naturally transitions into examining the collection of all potential measurement outcomes, which is referred to as the effect algebra, a new state space.
Moreover, measurement calculus offers a method for explaining how various measurement processes can be integrated into more intricate systems through the use of instruments.
In conclusion, the measurement calculus encompasses an explanation of the outcomes that arise when we measure a system whose state is only partially known, accompanied by a degree of uncertainty.
The measurement calculus was initially introduced by Aharonov and colleagues, and since that time, numerous papers have been published discussing its properties and various applications.

We present findings from cosmological simulations designed to investigate the formation and evolution of satellite galaxies in clusters that have been tidally stripped, which we term "tidal dwarfs" (TDs).
Our findings indicate that tidal tails are created when gas-rich satellites lose material during their initial close approach to the cluster's gravitational well.
The resulting TDs possess masses that range from \(10^8 M_{\text{sun}}\) to \(10^{10} M_{\text{sun}}\), sizes less than 100 parsecs, and circular velocities exceeding 50 km/s.
After several orbits within the virial radius of their host galaxy, they evolve into more massive systems with increased surface brightness.
Our findings indicate that tidal disruptions (TDs) could account for a portion of the diffuse intracluster light seen around nearby rich clusters.
Tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) are compact star-forming entities that emerge within interacting or merging galaxies.

The origins of these phenomena remain a topic of debate, but it has been proposed that they occur when gas-rich satellites come close enough to the center of their parent galaxy to experience tidal disruption.
In this study, we investigate the formation and evolution of tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) through high-resolution hydrodynamical cosmological zoom-in simulations conducted with the RAMSES-RT code.
We demonstrate that tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) can form as a result of the disruption of gas-rich satellites during their initial pericentric approach within the halo of the host galaxy.
These TDGs generally have masses ranging from 10^8 M⊙ to 10^11 M⊙, sizes smaller than 100 parsecs, and circular velocities exceeding 50 km/s.
After multiple orbital periods, these TDGs increase in mass and size, resulting in a brighter and bluer appearance.
In conclusion, our findings suggest that tidal dwarf galaxies (TDGs) may account for as much as 50% of the total diffuse intra-cluster light detected around nearby rich galaxy clusters.

We have determined that this model can explain all experimental data using just a single free parameter, which corresponds to the ratio of the two vacuum expectation values of the Higgs fields that are responsible for the breakdown of Pati-Salam gauge symmetry into the Standard Model gauge group.
The elements of the CKM matrix were anticipated, along with the Majorana phase linked to leptonic CP violation.

Furthermore, we demonstrate how the tri-bimaximal pattern seen in experimental observations within the lepton sector arises naturally when the quark-lepton unification hypothesis is applied at high energy levels.

We present new high-resolution near-infrared (NIR) spectra for the coolest known members of the open clusters M67 and NGC 2516, acquired using the Phoenix spectrograph at the Gemini South Observatory.
The observations aimed to investigate the sodium doublet at wavelengths 8183 and 8195 Å, along with other atomic characteristics that are influenced by surface gravity and effective temperature.

In conclusion, we analyze our obtained values in relation to those reported in earlier research and explore potential explanations for the variations observed among different studies.
Keywords: Near-infrared spectroscopy, open cluster, surface gravity, differential rotation, fundamental parameters.

We share recent findings from the outer jets of the symbiotic star R Aqr (also known as V1016 Cyg).
We examined archival Chandra data collected from August 31, 1999, to September 30, 2000, along with XMM-Newton observations recorded from October 24, 2001, to November 3, 2002.
The analysis indicates that both jets remained active at least until January 1, 2004.

Additionally, we present findings from an optical spectroscopic campaign conducted with the Nordic Optical Telescope from December 10 to 17, 2003, which showed no substantial differences when compared to earlier campaigns.
In conclusion, we examine our results in relation to existing theories regarding the formation of bipolar nebulae surrounding evolved stars.

The phenomenon of symbiosis can lead to the formation of jets in bipolar nebulae, driven by stellar winds and mass ejection from binary star systems. Observations from both the Chandra Observatory and the XMM-Newton Observatory have provided valuable insights into this process, particularly in systems like R Aquarius and V1016 Cyg.
We introduce an algorithm for identifying galaxy groups by utilizing photometric redshifts, which is built upon the Voronoi tessellation technique (VT).

The VT method has been extensively utilized for detecting clusters of galaxies based on spectroscopic redshifts; however, it has not yet been employed to identify galaxy groups using photometric redshifts.
Our input sample consists of data from the fifth release of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS DR5).
Our findings demonstrate that the VT method is effective for identifying galaxy groups, even when only photometric redshifts are accessible.
In this study, we identified over 12,000 galaxy groups within the redshift range of 0 to 0.3.
The groups include approximately 30,000 member galaxies.
Additionally, we offer a catalog that includes essential details such as positions, magnitudes, colors, and photometric redshifts for each of these groups.

Keywords: Galaxy Group, Photometric Redshift

The Galaxy Group is a collection of galaxies bound together by gravity, and researchers often measure their distances using photometric redshift techniques. Photometric redshift allows astronomers to estimate the distance to galaxies based on their light's color, providing valuable insights into the structure and evolution of the universe. By analyzing these distances, scientists can better understand the dynamics and composition of galaxy groups.
We showcase new findings on interstellar absorption lines observed in early-type stars using UVES at the Very Large Telescope (VLT), as part of the ESO-POP project (ESO program 085.D-0571).
We have investigated high-velocity clouds (HVCs) by examining the blueshifted features in the MgII doublet line profiles.
The sample comprises 16 OB stars situated within 1 kpc of Earth.
Alongside the previously identified high-velocity clouds (HVCs), we have discovered several new ones.
Some of these are connected to adjacent galaxies, while others could be linked to gas in the Galactic halo.
A comparison of our data set with earlier surveys indicates that there are no substantial differences in the number density distribution of HVCs across various sightlines.
This indicates that the majority of them are compact structures that occupy a limited solid angle around their host galaxy or star.

The interstellar medium is the matter that exists in the space between stars within a galaxy. It comprises a mixture of gas, dust, and cosmic rays, playing a crucial role in the formation of new stars and the evolution of galaxies. This medium is vital for understanding various astrophysical processes and phenomena.
We investigate second-harmonic (SH) and third-harmonic (TH) generation within an inhomogeneously broadened cavity that has two distinct resonance frequencies for the fundamental wave (FW).

We demonstrate that when the intracavity FW intensity is at its peak, the enhancement of both second harmonic generation (SHG) and third harmonic generation (THG) can be achieved simultaneously by either increasing the pumping rate or reducing the detuning between the two modes.
The improvement is attributed to the nonlinear susceptibility exceeding zero at this juncture.
Recent experiments have observed this effect.
Additionally, we discover a distinct regime in which only one type of harmonics can be produced efficiently, effectively suppressing all other types of harmonics.

For instance, when the intracavity frequency wave (FW) field is adjusted near the lower mode frequency, it primarily produces second harmonic (SH) light with minimal generation of third harmonic (TH) light. Conversely, when the intracavity FW field is set near the upper mode frequency, it predominantly generates TH light while producing very little SH light.

We introduce an atlas depicting the phase space of all possible motions in two-dimensional conservative Lagrangian mechanical systems, specifically those characterized by possessing one first and one second quadratic integral of motion.

The construction relied on a specific type of canonical transformation that transforms each system into another, allowing for the explicit determination of its trajectories as solutions to quadrature equations.
We demonstrate how this approach enables us to derive explicit formulas for the general solutions of specific problems, including those related to the harmonic oscillator and the Kepler problem.
The findings presented here extend previous research that focused solely on integrable cases.
They also offer fresh perspectives on the architecture of these types of systems.
Additionally, we present several examples that demonstrate our approach.

We investigate simple shear flow using two distinct inelastic Maxwell models: one featuring a constant restitution coefficient and the other exhibiting a restitution coefficient that varies with velocity.

Our findings indicate that a steady-state solution does not exist in a system characterized solely by elastic collisions; however, such a solution does arise when dissipative effects are incorporated.
The steady state solutions are determined to be unaffected by initial conditions or the type of dissipation involved.
Furthermore, we demonstrate that these steady states remain linearly stable when subjected to small perturbations.
In conclusion, we provide findings on the relaxation time scales related to this issue, which can be utilized to estimate how quickly the system converges to its steady state.

Recent studies [9] - [11] have demonstrated that, despite the potentially complex microscopic dynamics found in systems such as granular particles, the macroscopic behavior can still be accurately described using simpler kinetic equations, such as the Boltzmann equation or the Enskog equation [12].
Nevertheless, the majority of these studies focus on the elastic interactions among the particles, often overlooking the impact of dissipation.
This assumption is not always applicable, particularly in situations where particles interact through soft potentials.

We examined the redshifts of two samples of active galactic nuclei (AGNs) characterized by varying luminosities and discovered indications of intrinsic redshift components in each sample.
The initial sample includes 12 Seyfert galaxies, which are bright active galactic nuclei (AGNs) characterized by their broad emission lines.

We observe that the redshifts they exhibit can be separated into two components: an extrinsic component resulting from gravitational lensing by foreground objects, and an intrinsic component, the magnitude of which correlates with the widths of the broad emission lines.
This relationship indicates that the intrinsic redshift could be the result of Doppler shifts linked to the inflows or outflows of gas at scales similar to those examined in the broad-line region.
The second sample consists of low-luminosity quasars chosen from the quasar catalog of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey Data Release 4.
These quasars do not display any clear indications of gravitational lensing; however, they do demonstrate notable intrinsic redshift components.
In this instance, we observe a strong correlation between the amplitudes of these components and the optical continuum slopes measured at rest-frame wavelengths around 3000 Å.

We share the findings of our research regarding the chemical composition, molecular line emissions, dust characteristics, and thermal balance within dense cores that have metallicities varying from 1/100 to 1/10,000 of the solar level.
Our results indicate that the gas temperature drops by approximately 10 K with increasing core density across all metallicities examined (ranging from 1/100 to 1/10,000 of solar).
The decline is occurring more quickly than the forecasts made by existing models, which assume that temperatures remain constant during the evolution of the cloud.
This may be attributed to the growing significance of grain-surface chemistry in comparison to gas-phase reactions at elevated densities.
Through our analysis, we discover substantial evidence of carbon depletions onto grains, even at high metallicities, such as Z = 1/10,000 of solar abundance.
Our findings indicate that the critical density at which CO becomes optically thick is highly dependent on metallicity.
At lower metallicities, this happens at higher densities than it does at higher metallicities.
In conclusion, we demonstrate that the observed abundance ratios align with those anticipated if the clouds were originally enriched chemically by Type II supernovae.

We present findings on five newly discovered planets identified by the NASA K2 mission, which were detected among the targets observed during Campaigns 1 and 2 (C1/K2).

We provide a clear explanation of the higher algebraic K-groups using specific universal cohomology classes that are defined solely through the ring structure and the identity element of the underlying commutative ring.
This was carried out for any commutative ring with unity R, regardless of whether it is Noetherian or not.

The key finding can be expressed as follows: Let M be a module over R. There is a natural isomorphism between the higher algebraic K-groups, specifically K_n(R) and Ext^n_R(M, R), and the group of n-fold Massey products on M, modulo those that vanish under certain appropriate finiteness conditions.
We also demonstrate that this theorem provides a new proof of Quillen's localization theorem.
In conclusion, we will examine the applications in the realm of equivariant K-theory.

Specifically, we demonstrate that if G is a compact Lie group acting freely on a smooth manifold X, then the equivariant K-theory groups of X are isomorphic to the ordinary K-theory groups of the fixed point set, denoted as X^G.
In this study, we introduce an effective direct-voting approach designed to ensure data fusion assurance (DFA) in wireless sensor networks (WSNs).

The suggested DFA scheme is founded on the idea that each node can directly compare its local decision with those of other nodes and ultimately arrive at a final global decision through a majority voting process.

To minimize the communication overhead associated with the direct voting process, our approach implements two innovative techniques: 1) only one-hop neighboring nodes are permitted to cast their votes at any given moment; 2) all nodes utilize distinct time slots to transmit their votes concurrently.
We additionally provide a theoretical analysis demonstrating the potential energy savings achieved in comparison to existing methods.
In conclusion, comprehensive simulation results indicate that our method surpasses the most advanced techniques regarding accuracy and power efficiency.
Keywords: Data fusion verification, Wireless sensor networks, Energy-efficient direct voting mechanism.

The Standard Model (SM) is a highly successful theory; however, it faces several issues that must be resolved before we can confidently assert that we have discovered a "theory of everything."
The Standard Model fails to clarify the reasons behind the existence of three generations of quarks and leptons with varying masses, nor does it explain how neutrinos obtain their mass.
It also does not offer any insights into the nature of dark matter in our universe.
In this presentation, I will explore my latest research aimed at tackling these challenges by introducing new particles to the Standard Model that interact solely through gravitational forces.
These newly discovered particles are known as gravitons, and they possess a spin-2 quantum number, similar to the graviton in general relativity.

We demonstrate that the existence of gravitons results in interactions with other fields that give rise to generation-dependent masses for fermions, as well as introducing small Majorana masses for neutrinos.
Gravitons also play a role in the universe's energy density, potentially offering a solution to the issue of missing dark matter.
In conclusion, we suggest that gravitons could be crucial for elucidating the relationship between the Planck scale and the electroweak scale.

We investigate the phase diagram and electronic properties of the bilayer ruthenate Sr3Ru2O7 through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Our findings indicate that this material is on the verge of an insulator-metal transition due to charge transfer between its layers.
We observe a significant alteration in the Fermi surface topology as we cross the metal-insulator boundary, marked by the emergence of new hole pockets at the center of the Brillouin zone.
The calculated band gap is in good agreement with experimental results obtained from single crystals.
Furthermore, we anticipate the existence of two opposing nematic phases in proximity to the metal-insulator transition.
One exhibits in-plane anisotropy along the direction of the Ru-O-Ru bonds, while the other displays out-of-plane anisotropy that is perpendicular to this direction.
These findings offer valuable insights into the source of the structural distortion observed in bilayer ruthenates.
Bilayer ruthenates have garnered significant interest lately because of their diverse physical properties, which encompass unconventional superconductivity and quantum criticality.
and the phenomenon of multiferroicity.
